page.title: 17ECOLOGY OF PULBOROUGH.
page.content: The plants living on the hilly part of Pulborough differ from those in the River Arun valley. We scrambled down a steep slope to see the Brooks.The ground was flat and marshy, with long grass and clover. In the distance were a few trees, with some cows grazing, and beyond the river rose the south downs. A ridge ran beside the river, made by the mud dredged from the river. Rushes and flowers like Knotgrass, were in the field among the different kinds of grass. In the water were reeds, sedges and Water Plantain. Up the hill near the school, the landscape was different. There were hedges and many Hawthorn and Elderberry trees, Nettles, Hogweed and Thistles. There were fewer kinds of grass than on the Brooks. We saw Daisies, Dandelions, Speedwell, Vetch, Shepherd's Purse and Mayweed.
